html:
Cutting edge topical treatment for fine lines and wrinkles

Fine lines and wrinkles around the eyes have long been a concern of many. Current treatments have included everything from collagen injections to face lifts—all with varying degrees of effectiveness and risk of side effects.

Special election could decide tax hike, budget vote

The victor in this month's special election for At-large Councilmember could be the deciding vote on a contentious budget plan by Mayor Vincent Gray that is drawing starkly mixed reviews from Councilmembers.

Miss America visits Café Milano

Miss America Teresa Scanlan met with Education Secretary Arne Duncan last week, then had lunch at Café Milano in Georgetown. Scanlan and media guru Tammy Haddad speak with Hollywood on the Potomac.

Mandarin Oriental Hotel hosts Bassin's barrel tasting

There wasn’t a barrel in site at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel Saturday as The 26th California Futures Tasting got underway.

The lyrical palette of Robert Rea on view at Susan Calloway Fine Arts

Opening at Susan Calloway Fine Arts this Saturday, April 2, 2011 and continuing through April 16 is "Robert Rea: A Lyrical Palette," an exhibition of abstract paintings.

Catania considers run for AG as scandals mount

At-large Councilmember David Catania indicated interest in a run for Attorney General when that position becomes an elected post in 2014. "I'm open to that," he said on WPFW's D.C. Politics hour Thursday.
Candidates support more ethics, less university expansion

Branded ... ?

There is one question I receive more than any other from prospective clients, writers, editors, vendors and the public-at-large. “What’s Your Style?” Simple enough I suppose.
The Magical World of Frank Babb Randolph

The Georgetown Dish live on WPFW 89.3 FM at 11:00 am

The Georgetown Dish will join WPFW's Politics Hour with at-large Council candidate Sekou Biddle and host Chuck Thies today at 11:00 am to discuss recent scandals plaguing the D.C. government and the upcoming Council election April 26.

Obama talks energy policy, basketball at Georgetown U.

President Barack Obama yesterday delivered a speech at Georgetown University, calling for a one-third reduction in U.S. oil imports by 2025 and increased alternative energy sources.

2011 D.C. Design House Chooses Jewel Tones

"It doesn't cost anything to dream," said well-known interior designer Robert Shields of this D.C. Design House. The Prospect St. resident says he "loves everything about Georgetown."

Witness to history: Tudor Place a Georgetown treasure

Built between 1795 and 1816 on a whole city block (on 31st between Q and R Streets), Tudor Place illuminates the history of Georgetown, the “mother” of the nation’s capital. Six generations of the Peter family lived at Tudor Place.

Circulator plan adds new routes

By Brady Holt

Current Staff Writer

Down with fashion faux pas and wardrobe malfunctions

When the Washington climate changes suddenly, as it is wont to do, and I am furiously searching through closets for a Spring jacket or slicker, I think longingly of having my own stylist.

Northern Exposure

Last week, when I thought it was spring, I yanked the straggly hydrangeas and ailing boxwoods from my front walk, leaving a lovely blank space, just begging for new plants. My front walk is on the north side of the house.

Bagging it at the Social Safeway

NBC Washington's Kimberly Suiters and Fresh 94.7 DJ Tommy McFly were among those who bagged their Saturday for the Washington Humane Society.

Watch the video at NBC Nightside.

Georgetown Tobacco's 47th anniversary sale through Monday, April 4

Extended through Monday, April 4, Georgetown Tobacco is celebrating their 47th anniversary with a very special sale.

Georgetown’s population didn’t boom that much afterall

Last Friday, GM posted a particularly breathless report on the huge jump in the population count for Georgetown in last year’s census. The overall increase was 1,791, a 21.01% increase.
Wine tasting extraordinaire

GBA legislative committee meets on health care insurance for small businesses

Georgetown businesses, like many across the country, are faced with difficult questions on health care and how to deal with new mandates imposed by Congress. Last week, GBA's legislative committee met with Brendan Rose, Health Care Policy Analyst for the D.C.

Georgetown’s population booms

Thursday, the U.S. Census released the results for the 2010 Census for D.C.

USA TODAY reports possible DCPS test fraud

More questions are dogging DCPS when it comes to test scores. Georgetown schools do not appear to be among the offending schools named by USA TODAY Sunday as having abnormally high rates of erasures on tests during the official spring testing period during the last three years.

Foraging for lunch at 1789

For 26-year old executive chef, Daniel Giusti and newest member of the 1789 culinary team, pastry chef Mallory Staley, Sunday morning at this historic Georgetown restaurant was all about “teaching cooking and having fun.”

Lobbyists sweeten the deal with Georgetown Cupcakes

Controversy is already swirling around the proposed merger of AT&T and T-Mobile, but the New York Times reports on a secret confection involved in the deal: Georgetown Cupcakes.

'Out & About' Launch Party at L2 April 20

The Georgetown Business Association and The Georgetown Dish are hosting the national launch of Out & About, a

new channel for news and social media in Georgetown because "Georgetown Means Business."

Mix and mingle at D.C. Chamber speed networking event March 31

D.C.

GBA and BID offer boot camp for business

The Georgetown Business Association (GBA) and the Georgetown Business Improvement District (BID) are teaming up to offer a series of "boot camp briefings" for Georgetown businesses.

Editorial: Mayor should talk to Chuck and say bye-bye

It is time for Mayor Vincent Gray to demand that Charles Brodsky, chairman of the powerful Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) Board resign -- now -- because Mr. Brodsky has lost the public trust. Mr.

The Georgetown Current endorses Biddle for at-large Council race

For every mayoral and D.C. Council election, we conduct three-hour interviews with candidates vying for the votes of Northwest residents. From those conversations and other observations, we have formed opinions on the current at-large D.C. Council hopefuls.

Much Ado About Nothing

I had my heart set on a particular feature this week, but I can’t find the key image. And although I have 30 or so folders containing potential posts stocked away in my computer, I’m just not feeling it for any of them right now.

Truly unique Georgetown property for sale

GM mentioned this briefly last week, but this calls for a bit more discussion: the Stables of Georgetown property (1316 33rd St.) is on the market.

Superior Homes Services honored for Georgetown restoration

Recently recognized by the National Association of the Remodeling Industry (NARI) with the 2010 Capitol COTY (Contractor of the Year) Award, Superior Home Services, Inc.

Join Rokas Berseniovas, Janine Schoonover, Wendy Gordon and Tanya Sabel as they host "The Rhino Grows Paws," a Fashion 4 Paws Fundraiser Monday March 28

Get juiced at Eastern Holistic Arts

Eastern Holistic Arts (EHA) is offering a special phDetox Cleanse, a week of raw juicing from March 28 through April 1, 2011. As Tracy Hackett, EHA owner explains, "Cleansing with raw juices gives the body a refreshing and inv

Alcohol board reversed policy to favor Brodsky friend

The Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) Board led by Chairman Charles Brodsky recently reversed a longstanding policy in favor of one distributor after a friend of Brodsky's took over as the distributor's attorney, according to documents obtained by The Georgetown Dish.

Café Bonaparte: at home In Georgetown

In July 2003, the Popal family launched Café Bonaparte, one of Washington’s most popular and beloved Parisian coffeeshop/creperies and the first of their two successful French-themed restaurants in the nation’s capital.

Forbes says: It’s time to shift from renting to homeownership in DC

In the past few years, the U.S. government has encouraged homeownership by initiating the First Time Home Buyers tax credit and keeping interest rates at their lowest levels since the end of World War II.

Brodsky will not be reappointed, says Mayor

Mayor Vince Gray said Wednesday he will not reappoint Charles Brodsky, the controversial Alcohol chairman recently accused of ethics violations.

ABC board member resigns, charging ethics violations by Brodsky

A senior member of the Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) Board has resigned, charging Chairman Charles Brodsky with lobbying fellow Board members illegally to support a major policy change that would advance Brodsky's

St. John's plans $2 million in upgrades

By Allison Brennan

Current Correspondent

Parishioners at St. John’s Episcopal Church in Georgetown gathered on Friday to kick off a five-year fundraising effort focused on renovating the worship space in the centuries-old church.

Black ties, chucks, and a non-surprise surprise

You may not know who Paul Cohn is, but If you’ve ever lit up a cigar at Old Glory, gotten picked up at J. Paul’s, dished at Paolo’s or had hummus at Neyla, then send him a thank-you note.

Tennessee Williams Centennial Festival at Georgetown University

From March 24-27, Georgetown University will host fully staged productions, interactive multimedia experiences, workshops, concerts, screenings, and discussions as part of the Tennessee Williams Centennial Festival. This ambitious, multifaceted celebration honor

Lululemon murder suspect worked at Georgetown store

Brittany Norwood, a suspect in a brutal murder of another employee in Bethesda's Lululemon Athletica store, had recently transferred from the Georgetown store on M Street, authorities said Monday.

Georgetowners nosh and josh at CAG tasting

Georgetown's most popular chefs mingled with members of the Citizens Association of Georgetown (CAG) Monday at Boffi's elegant kitchen showroom in Cady's Alley.

Miller brothers launch WestMill Capital

For Benjamin and Daniel Miller, WestMill Capital, their newly launched real estate company, soon to be headquartered in Dupont Circle above Kramerbooks, represents both a continuation of the family business and a nod to a younger demographic.

Orange rolls into high gear with campaign kick-off

Serendipity3 Founder Comes to Georgetown

Eastern Holistic Arts offers Special Spring Cleansing

In honor of spring, Eastern Holistic Arts (EHA) is offering pHDetox Cleanse, a week of raw juicing from March 28 through April 1.

Michelle Obama to publish secrets...of the garden

First Lady Michelle Obama will publish a book next April, as yet untitled, that "will tell the story of the garden she has established on the South Lawn of the White House and explore how improved access to fresh, locally grown food can promote healthier eating habits for famili
